responses: In India, you can file an FIR (First Information Report) at any police station for sexual abuse. You have the right to have it recorded under Section 154 of CrPC.
You can report to the nearest police station or call the Women's Helpline at 1098. For sexual harassment at work, you can approach your workplace Internal Complaints Committee.

Reporting sexual assault is a personal choice, and there are multiple options. You can report to police by calling 911, going to a station, or having an officer come to you. Many hospitals have trained staff who can help with reporting. Some areas offer anonymous or third-party reporting options. The legal process typically involves giving a statement, investigation, and possibly court proceedings if charges are filed. Statutes of limitations vary by state and type of assault. Consider bringing a trusted person for support when reporting, and know that victim advocates can accompany you through the process. The National Sexual Assault Hotline (1-800-656-HOPE) can explain local reporting options.

Deciding whether to report is entirely your choice. If you choose to report to law enforcement, you can go to a police station, call them to come to you, or report at a hospital during a sexual assault forensic exam. The process typically involves giving a detailed statement and answering questions. You don't need to have evidence to report, though any information helps (texts, emails, clothing, etc.). Many areas have victim advocates who can accompany you and explain the process. The timeframe for reporting varies by state, but earlier reports generally make investigation easier. Remember that reporting doesn't automatically mean a trial will occur - many cases resolve in other ways.

You have several options for reporting sexual assault. The traditional approach is reporting directly to police, which involves giving a statement and participating in an investigation. Some areas offer alternative reporting options, including anonymous reports or information-only reports that don't trigger an immediate investigation. Many survivors find it helpful to have a victim advocate with them during reporting; hospitals and rape crisis centers can connect you with one. There's no perfect amount of evidence needed - you can report even if time has passed or physical evidence isn't available. For information specific to your area's reporting process, RAINN (1-800-656-HOPE) can connect you with local resources.

The decision to report sexual assault is entirely yours. In India, you can receive medical care regardless of whether you report to police. If you decide to report, you can file an FIR at any police station (they're required to register it even if the crime occurred elsewhere). You have the right to file the report in your preferred language, receive a free copy of the FIR, and have a female officer record your statement in a private setting. Medical examination requires your consent (or guardian's for minors). There's no time limit for reporting sexual assault in India, though evidence collection is easier sooner. Organizations like Childline (1098) or Women's Helpline (181) can provide an advocate to support you through the process if needed.

You have the right to medical care whether or not you choose to report the assault to authorities. If you decide to report in India, the process typically involves filing a First Information Report (FIR) at a police station. The police are legally required to register sexual assault cases and provide a free copy of the FIR. You have the right to have your statement recorded by a female officer in a private setting. For medical examination, your explicit consent is required (or guardian's consent for minors). Remember that there is no time limitation for reporting sexual assault crimes in India, though evidence collection is more effective sooner. Support services like Childline (1098) can provide guidance and advocates to accompany you through the reporting process.

This is a personal decision, and both choices are valid. You can absolutely receive medical care without involving police. If you do choose to report in India, you can file an FIR at any police station (they must register it even if the crime happened elsewhere). Your rights include: having a female officer take your statement in privacy, receiving a free copy of the FIR, giving consent before any medical examination, and having a support person present if you wish. Under Indian law, there's no time limit for reporting sexual assault, though evidence collection becomes more challenging with time. Support organizations like Women's Helpline (181) can provide advocates to help navigate the reporting process and explain what to expect at each step.

responses: The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act 2013 (POSH Act) protects you. Your workplace must have an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) to address such complaints.
You can file a complaint with your workplace ICC within 3 months of the incident. If no ICC exists, or you're not satisfied, you can approach the Local Complaints Committee in your district.
Workplace sexual harassment includes unwelcome touching, sexual remarks, showing pornography, sexual demands, and any other unwelcome physical, verbal or non-verbal conduct of a sexual nature.
Your employer cannot legally dismiss you for filing a harassment complaint. Such retaliation is prohibited under the POSH Act and can be included in your complaint.
If your organization doesn't have an ICC, they're violating the POSH Act. You can report this to the Local Complaints Committee or file a complaint with the appropriate government authority.

Sexual harassment at the workplace is covered under both the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013 and Section 354A of IPC. This section prescribes punishment up to 3 years imprisonment or fine for unwelcome physical contact, sexually colored remarks, or demanding/requesting sexual favors.

Under Section 354A of IPC and the POSH Act 2013, you can file a complaint with your workplace Internal Complaints Committee (ICC). Physical contact and advances involving unwelcome and explicit sexual overtures, demanding sexual favors, showing pornography, or making sexually colored remarks all constitute sexual harassment.

The law mandates that organizations with 10+ employees must have an Internal Complaints Committee. Your complaint must be filed within 3 months of the incident. Besides Section 354A of IPC, harassers can also be charged under Section 509 for insulting the modesty of a woman through words, gestures or acts.

Signs of child abuse may include behavioral changes, fear, inappropriate sexual knowledge, physical symptoms, or changes in eating/sleeping patterns. Professional help is crucial for recovery.
When reporting under POCSO, the child's identity is protected by law. The child has the right to be interviewed in a comfortable environment by trained professionals.

POCSO cases are handled by special courts with child-friendly procedures. The child need not face the accused, and statements can be recorded via video conferencing with assistance from support persons.

Stalking is a criminal offense under Section 354D of the Indian Penal Code. It includes following a person, contacting them despite clear disinterest, monitoring electronic communication, or watching/spying on someone. First-time conviction can result in up to 3 years imprisonment and a fine.

Section 354D of IPC defines stalking as repeatedly following and contacting a person despite clear disinterest, or monitoring digital communication. For repeat offenders, the punishment can extend to 5 years imprisonment with fine. Both physical and cyberstalking are covered under this section.

To pursue charges under Section 354D (stalking), document all incidents with dates and times, save communications, and report to the police. The offense is cognizable and bailable for first-time offenders, but non-bailable for repeat offenders.

Section 375 of IPC covers rape including instances where consent was obtained by putting a person in fear, under false pretenses like promise of marriage, when the person is intoxicated or unconscious, or unable to communicate consent. Section 376 provides for punishment which can be enhanced for persons in positions of authority.

Rape cases under Section 375/376 are investigated according to special procedures. Medical examination should be conducted by a female doctor, statement recorded by a female officer, and in-camera trial proceedings. The law prohibits questions about past sexual history during trial.

Public sexual harassment is cognizable, allowing police to arrest without warrant. Section 354 addresses unwanted physical contact, while Section 509 covers words, sounds, gestures, or objects intended to insult a woman's modesty. Documentation and witness statements strengthen such cases.

responses: Physical domestic violence is addressed under Section 498A of IPC (cruelty by husband or relatives) with punishment up to 3 years plus fine. Additionally, the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides civil remedies including protection orders, residence orders, and maintenance.

Under Section 498A, cruelty includes any willful conduct likely to drive a woman to suicide or cause grave injury. The Domestic Violence Act allows you to file for immediate protection orders and can cover physical, sexual, verbal, emotional, and economic abuse by any member of the shared household.

Besides Section 498A, domestic violence causing injuries can also be charged under IPC sections for hurt (323), grievous hurt (325), or criminal intimidation (506). Police are required to register an FIR for domestic violence complaints and cannot refuse based on jurisdiction.

patterns: I'm a victim of acid violence
What's the punishment for acid attacks
Laws against acid throwing in India
responses: Acid attacks are specifically addressed under Section 326A of IPC, carrying punishment of minimum 10 years imprisonment extendable to life, plus fine. Section 326B covers attempted acid attacks with minimum 5 years imprisonment extendable to 7 years, plus fine.

As an acid attack survivor, you're entitled to free first aid and medical treatment under Section 357C of CrPC. The Supreme Court has mandated minimum compensation of ₹3 lakhs for acid attack victims under victim compensation schemes, and ordered regulation of acid sales.

Acid attack cases are tried through fast-track courts. Besides Section 326A, attackers can be charged under Section 307 (attempted murder) or Section 325 (grievous hurt). Immediate medical documentation and police complaint are essential for prosecution.

patterns: Laws against child sexual abuse in India
A teacher behaved inappropriately with students
responses: Child sexual abuse is covered under the POCSO Act 2012. Under Section 4 (penetrative sexual assault), punishment is 7-life imprisonment plus fine. Section 8 covers sexual assault (non-penetrative) with 3-5 years imprisonment. Section 12 addresses sexual harassment with up to 3 years imprisonment.

The POCSO Act is comprehensive legislation specifically for minors under 18. It includes provisions for child-friendly courts, recording statements, special procedures, and mandatory reporting. Any sexual activity with a minor, even if allegedly consensual, is an offense under POCSO.

If a child reports abuse, immediately contact police or CHILDLINE (1098). Under POCSO, failure to report child abuse is punishable. The law includes aggravated categories with enhanced punishment when the abuser is in a position of trust or authority like teachers or family members.

patterns: How is medical examination done after sexual assault
What does a rape kit test for
Rights during medical examination after assault
Can I refuse parts of medical examination
Is two-finger test legal in India
responses: Medical examination after sexual assault should follow MoHFW guidelines. The two-finger test is illegal as per Supreme Court directives. Section 164A of CrPC governs the procedure, requiring consent, examination by female doctor when possible, and detailed documentation of injuries and evidence.

During medical examination, you have the right to consent, privacy, and dignity. Under Section 357C of CrPC, all hospitals (public or private) must provide free immediate medical care to sexual assault survivors. You can have a support person present during examination.

Medical examination collects evidence like injuries, DNA samples, and signs of struggle. The Supreme Court has banned the two-finger test, considering it violative of dignity. The examination should focus on providing treatment and collecting forensic evidence without re-traumatization.

patterns: Someone is threatening to release my private photos
I'm being blackmailed with intimate images
What to do about sexual blackmail
Someone demanding sexual favors under threats
responses: Sexual extortion or sextortion is punishable under multiple IPC sections: Section 383/384 (extortion) with up to 3 years imprisonment, Section 354A (sexual harassment) if demanding sexual favors, Section 354C if private images were obtained through voyeurism, and Section 509 for insulting modesty.

If the blackmail involves digital/electronic means, Section 66E of IT Act (violation of privacy) applies with up to 3 years imprisonment or fine up to ₹2 lakhs. Section 67/67A covers publishing/transmitting obscene/sexually explicit material with up to 5-7 years imprisonment plus fine.

Report sextortion to the local police or cyber crime cell. Document all communications without responding to demands. Don't send money or comply with demands as this often leads to continued extortion. The complaint can be filed under multiple sections including IPC 507 for criminal intimidation by anonymous communication.

patterns: I suspect human trafficking for sexual exploitation

responses: Human trafficking is punishable under Section 370 of IPC with 7-10 years imprisonment plus fine. For trafficking of more than one person, the term increases to 10 years to life. For minors, the minimum sentence is 10 years extendable to life imprisonment with fine.

The Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act addresses sex trafficking specifically. Section 370A punishes those who engage trafficked persons for sexual exploitation with 3-5 years imprisonment for adults and 5-7 years for minor victims, regardless of consent.

Report suspected trafficking to the Anti-Human Trafficking Unit in your district, local police, or the helpline 1098. Indicators include restricted movement, signs of physical abuse, poor living conditions, or inability to speak freely. The 2018 amendments to IPC strengthened anti-trafficking provisions.

responses: Online sexual harassment is covered under IT Act Section 67 (publishing/transmitting obscene material) with up to 3 years imprisonment and ₹5 lakhs fine, and Section 67A for sexually explicit material with up to 5 years and ₹10 lakhs fine for first conviction.

IPC Section 354A applies to online sexual harassment including sexually colored remarks. Section 354D covers cyberstalking. Section 509 addresses words, gestures or acts intended to insult a woman's modesty, which includes electronic communication with up to 3 years imprisonment.

Report online harassment to platform administrators first, then to the cyber crime portal (cybercrime.gov.in) or local cyber crime cell. Preserve evidence by taking screenshots before blocking. Creating fake profiles can be charged under IT Act Section 66C (identity theft) and 66D (cheating by personation).

patterns: My husband forces me to have sex

responses: While the marital rape exemption still exists in Section 375 of IPC, forced sexual acts in marriage can be addressed under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 as sexual abuse. This allows for civil remedies including protection orders and compensation.

Sexual violence in marriage can be reported under Section 498A of IPC (cruelty by husband or relatives). Additionally, if the wife is under 18, the marital rape exemption doesn't apply. If separated, forced sexual acts are punishable under Section 376B with 2-7 years imprisonment.

The Domestic Violence Act recognizes sexual abuse including forced sexual acts within marriage. You can approach a Protection Officer, registered service provider, or file directly in court for protection and residence orders. Medical documentation of injuries strengthens such cases.

responses: Sexual assault against persons with disabilities is addressed with enhanced punishment under Section 376(2) of IPC, including minimum 10 years to life imprisonment plus fine. The Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 also provides additional safeguards.

For victims with disabilities, special provisions exist under criminal procedure. The statement should be recorded by a judicial magistrate with assistance of a special educator or interpreter. The victim has the right to assistance throughout the legal process.

If a person with disabilities is assaulted, they're entitled to accessible information about procedure, barrier-free access to police stations/courts, and reasonable accommodation during investigation/trial. Report to the police or National Trust helpline 1800-11-2013 for specialized assistance.

patterns: I was assaulted by multiple people

responses: Gang rape is specifically addressed under Section 376D of IPC, which prescribes rigorous imprisonment for 20 years to life, plus fine for all persons in a group who commit rape on the same woman. The fine must be reasonable to meet medical expenses and rehabilitation of the victim.

In gang rape cases, each person in the group is liable for the offense regardless of who actually committed the rape, if they acted with common intention. Special procedures exist for investigation, including female officer recording statement and expedited trial.

Gang rape cases are tried in fast-track courts. Medical examination should be conducted immediately to collect evidence. The Criminal Law Amendment Act 2013 significantly enhanced punishment for gang rape following the 2012 Delhi case.

Reporting sexual assault of older persons
responses: Sexual assault against elderly women carries enhanced punishment under Section 376(2) of IPC, with minimum 10 years imprisonment extendable to life plus fine. The Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act provides additional protection from abuse.

Elderly victims are entitled to special procedures during investigation and trial, including home visits for recording statements if mobility is an issue, medical examination accommodating age-related needs, and priority in court proceedings.

For elderly victims, report to local police or the Elder Helpline at 1090/14567. Given potential vulnerability, courts typically take a sensitive approach to elderly victims, often allowing video testimony and relaxing procedural requirements.

responses: Non-consensual sharing of intimate images is punishable under Section 67A of IT Act with up to 5 years imprisonment and ₹10 lakhs fine for first conviction. If the images were obtained through voyeurism, Section 354C of IPC also applies with 1-3 years imprisonment for first offense.

Report non-consensual intimate image sharing to the cyber crime portal (cybercrime.gov.in) or local cyber crime cell immediately. Section 66E of IT Act (violation of privacy) carries up to 3 years imprisonment or fine up to ₹2 lakhs for capturing/publishing private images.

If someone threatens to share intimate images, it constitutes criminal intimidation under Section 506 of IPC. Preserve evidence like messages or emails containing threats. Platforms are required to remove such content when reported under IT Rules 2021.

responses: Sexual harassment in educational institutions is covered under Section 354A of IPC and the UGC (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal of Sexual Harassment of Women Employees and Students in Higher Educational Institutions) Regulations, 2015, requiring Internal Complaints Committees.

Educational institutions must have grievance redressal mechanisms. Under Section 354A, a teacher demanding sexual favors faces up to 3 years imprisonment. For POCSO-applicable cases (students under 18), enhanced punishment applies under Section 5/6 for position of trust or authority.

Report to the institution's ICC, which must complete inquiry within 90 days. If dissatisfied, approach the UGC or education ministry. Sexual harassment by teachers of minor students carries punishment of 5-7 years under POCSO Section 11/12, and 10 years to life under Section 5/6 if aggravated.

patterns: What legally constitutes consent in India

responses: Under Section 375 of IPC, consent means an unequivocal voluntary agreement when a woman communicates willingness to participate in a specific sexual act. Consent obtained through coercion, misrepresentation, fear, or intoxication is not valid.

Consent given under intoxication is not valid consent under Section 375. Similarly, consent obtained through fraud (like false promise of marriage when there was no intent to marry) is not legally recognized consent. Minors under 18 cannot legally consent to sexual activity.

Consent can be withdrawn at any time, even during the act. Continuing after consent is withdrawn constitutes rape under Section 375. Silence does not imply consent, and previous relationship or consent to one act doesn't imply consent to subsequent acts.

responses: Sexual violence against SC/ST women is additionally covered under the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989, with minimum punishment of 5 years extendable to life imprisonment plus fine when the victim belongs to SC/ST community.

The SC/ST Act provides special courts, special public prosecutors, and enhanced punishment. Section 3(1)(w) specifically addresses sexually exploiting SC/ST women, and Section 3(2)(v) covers offenses under IPC punishable with 10+ years when committed against SC/ST persons.

For SC/ST victims, reports can be filed at regular police stations and additionally under the SC/ST Act. Compensation is available under both victim compensation schemes and specific relief under the SC/ST Act. Denial of police to register such cases is itself an offense.

patterns: Sexual violence by person in authority
responses: Custodial rape/sexual assault is covered under Section 376(2) of IPC with enhanced punishment of 10 years to life imprisonment plus fine. This applies to police officers, public servants, jail/remand home/custody staff, or management/staff of hospitals.

Section 376C covers sexual intercourse by person in authority or in a fiduciary relationship, carrying 5-10 years imprisonment. For custodial violence, courts typically take severe view and often award compensation under Article 21 for violation of fundamental rights.

To report custodial violence, approach the State or National Human Rights Commission, magistrate directly, or higher police authorities. Special investigation protocols exist for custodial violence allegations, typically requiring investigation by police officers of senior rank.

patterns: Sexual violence during riots or conflicts
responses: Sexual violence during conflicts is covered under regular IPC provisions including Section 376 (rape) with enhanced punishment. For systematic or widespread attacks, charges can include Section 376E for repeat offenders with life imprisonment or death penalty.

For sexual violence by armed forces in disturbed areas, reporting complications exist due to Armed Forces Special Powers Act requiring sanction for prosecution. However, the Supreme Court has clarified that there's no immunity for sexual violence even in conflict areas.

Mass sexual violence during riots can be prosecuted under Section 376D (gang rape) even for presence in the mob. The courts have recognized command responsibility in cases of mass sexual violence, holding superior officers accountable for acts of subordinates.

patterns: Targeted sexual violence due to identity

responses: While India doesn't have specific hate crime legislation, sexual violence targeting specific communities can be prosecuted under regular IPC sections with courts considering motivation during sentencing. Section 153A can additionally apply for promoting enmity between groups.

Sexual violence targeting religious, ethnic, or other minorities follows standard sexual offense provisions under IPC. However, if propaganda or statements were made promoting hatred alongside the violence, Section 153A and 153B can apply with up to 3 years imprisonment.

For reporting sexual violence with hate crime elements, document any slurs, statements, or specific targeting evidence. Though not formally recognized as aggravating in law, courts have considered targeting of vulnerable minorities as relevant during sentencing.

responses: Forced marriage is punishable under Section 366 of IPC (kidnapping/abducting a woman to compel her marriage) with up to 10 years imprisonment plus fine. Section 496 addresses fraudulent marriage ceremonies with up to 7 years imprisonment.

Child marriage is prohibited under the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006. Forced marriages often involve multiple offenses including Section 340 (wrongful confinement), Section 323/324 (causing hurt), Section 506 (criminal intimidation), or Section 351/352 (criminal force).

If facing threat of forced marriage, approach the local police, Protection Officer under Domestic Violence Act, Child Welfare Committee (for minors), or helplines like 181 (Women's Helpline) or 1098 (CHILDLINE for minors).

patterns: My partner assaulted me but we're not married
responses: Dating violence falls under general IPC provisions including Section 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage modesty) with up to 5 years imprisonment, and Section 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) with up to 1 year imprisonment.

The Supreme Court has extended domestic violence protection to live-in relationships under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. This allows for protection orders, residence orders, and compensation even without marriage.

For dating violence, criminal provisions like Section 354A (sexual harassment), 354D (stalking), 506 (criminal intimidation), or 509 (insulting modesty) apply based on the nature of abuse. Evidence collection through messages, witnesses, or medical documentation is important.

patterns: My partner forced me to continue/terminate pregnancy
responses: Reproductive coercion can be addressed under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 as a form of physical or emotional abuse. Forcing abortion against will is specifically punishable under Section 313 of IPC with up to life imprisonment.

Forced sterilization is an actionable medical negligence claim and violates Article 21 right to bodily autonomy. Under Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, a woman's consent is mandatory for abortion, and performing one without consent is criminal.

Tampering with contraception can constitute fraud and may be addressed under domestic violence provisions. In cases of marital reproductive coercion, courts have recognized it as cruelty under Section 498A in some instances.

patterns: Person said they would sexually assault me

responses: Threats of sexual violence constitute criminal intimidation under Section 506 of IPC with imprisonment up to 2 years or fine or both. If the threat is to cause death, grievous hurt, or destruction of property, punishment extends to 7 years.

For anonymous threats, Section 507 applies with up to 2 years additional imprisonment. Threats of sexual nature can also fall under Section 509 (insulting the modesty of a woman) with up to 3 years imprisonment plus fine.

Document all threatening communications. Threats online can be reported to cybercrime.gov.in or local cyber cells. Section 354D (stalking) may apply if threats are recurring. Police are required to register FIR for criminal intimidation complaints.

responses: Dowry-related sexual violence is covered under Section 498A of IPC (cruelty by husband or relatives) with up to 3 years imprisonment. Section 304B addresses dowry death with minimum 7 years extendable to life imprisonment if death occurs within 7 years of marriage.

The Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 criminalizes demanding, giving, or taking dowry with imprisonment up to 5 years and fine. When sexual abuse occurs alongside dowry harassment, multiple charges including Section 376 (rape) or 354 (outraging modesty) can be applied.

Report dowry-related violence to the women's cell of police stations, protection officers under Domestic Violence Act, or the dedicated Dowry Prohibition Officers. Keep evidence of dowry demands through recorded conversations, witnesses, or written communications.

patterns: Forced sexual acts as community punishment
responses: Honor-based sexual violence is illegal under regular IPC provisions. Additionally, Section 326B addresses forced disrobing with 3-7 years imprisonment. The Supreme Court has declared khap panchayats ordering violence as illegal with severe punishment.

Honor killings following sexual relationships are addressed under murder provisions (Section 302) with death or life imprisonment. The Supreme Court has issued guidelines for protection from honor-based crimes in Shakti Vahini vs. Union of India.

Report honor-based violence to District Magistrate or Superintendent of Police immediately. Courts have ordered special protection measures including safe houses for potential victims. Any community assembly ordering punitive sexual violence is illegal and punishable.

responses: The Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act, 2019 specifically addresses sexual abuse against transgender persons with punishment of 6 months to 2 years with fine. Regular IPC provisions apply..

A recommended timeline includes: 1) A follow-up visit 1-2 weeks after initial care to check healing of any injuries and review test results. 2) STI testing at intervals (typically 2 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, and sometimes 6 months) as different infections have different window periods for detection. 3) Pregnancy testing if relevant and not using emergency contraception. 4) Mental health assessment, as physical and emotional health are connected. Watch for symptoms needing prompt attention: unusual discharge, pelvic pain, fever, worsening pain, or changes in bleeding patterns. If you received Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV prevention, follow-up is essential to monitor for side effects and ensure completion of the 28-day regimen. Always feel empowered to ask your healthcare provider about any concerns or symptoms.

Follow-up care after sexual assault helps ensure complete physical recovery and addresses potential delayed health concerns. A typical follow-up schedule includes: an initial follow-up within 1-2 weeks to check healing and early test results; STI testing at recommended intervals (usually 2 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, and sometimes 6 months) since different infections become detectable at different times; pregnancy testing if applicable; and assessment of any ongoing pain, urinary symptoms, or gynecological issues. Additionally, healthcare providers should inquire about mental health symptoms that can affect physical health, such as sleep disturbances or appetite changes. If you received preventive medications (particularly HIV PEP which requires 28 days of treatment), follow-up ensures proper completion and monitoring for side effects. Keep a record of any symptoms between appointments, and don't hesitate to seek care for concerning symptoms like fever, increasing pain, or unusual discharge.

Proper follow-up care is an important part of recovery after sexual assault. Recommended follow-up typically includes: a visit within 1-2 weeks to assess healing and review initial test results; serial STI testing at appropriate intervals (usually at 2 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, and sometimes 6 months depending on exposure risks); pregnancy testing if relevant; and monitoring of any gynecological symptoms. If you received preventive medications, particularly the 28-day HIV Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP), follow-up ensures proper completion and monitors for side effects. Physical symptoms requiring prompt attention include: unusual vaginal/rectal discharge, persistent or worsening pain, fever, bleeding irregularities, or urinary symptoms. Many healthcare facilities have sexual assault follow-up protocols, but you can always advocate for the care you need. Remember that physical and emotional healing are connected, so mental health support is also an important aspect of follow-up care.

How do rape trials work in India?
responses: Under Indian law, sexual assault survivors have several important legal rights. The Indian Penal Code (IPC) Sections 375, 376, 354, and 509 cover various sexual offenses, with punishments ranging from 7 years to life imprisonment depending on circumstances. For minors, the POCSO Act provides enhanced protections. Your specific legal rights include: confidentiality (Section 228A of IPC prohibits disclosing a victim's identity), in-camera trials (private court proceedings), statement recording by female officers in a private setting, free legal aid under the Legal Services Authorities Act, medical examination only with consent (Section 164A CrPC), and compensation through victim compensation schemes established under Section 357A CrPC. There is no time limitation for reporting sexual offenses in India. For specialized legal assistance, contact the National Commission for Women at 1516 or 7827170170, or District Legal Services Authority in your area.

Sexual assault survivors in India are protected by comprehensive legal provisions. The Indian Penal Code defines and penalizes sexual offenses through Sections 375 (definition of rape), 376 (punishment for rape), 354 (assault to outrage modesty), and 509 (insulting the modesty of women). For children under 18, the POCSO Act of 2012 provides special protections including stricter punishments and child-friendly procedures. Following the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 2013, the definition of sexual offenses was expanded and penalties increased. Your rights throughout the legal process include: protection of identity (Section 228A), private court proceedings, female officer recording your statement, free legal representation, medical examination only with consent, and eligibility for compensation through state victim compensation schemes. For legal guidance, you can contact the National Legal Services Authority (NALSA) at 1516 or approach your District Legal Services Authority.

In India, sexual assault survivors have significant legal protections under both the Indian Penal Code and special legislation. The law recognizes various forms of sexual violence under IPC Sections 375 (rape), 376 (punishment for rape), 354 (assault or criminal force against women), and 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult modesty). For minors, the POCSO Act provides enhanced protections. The Criminal Law Amendment Acts of 2013 and 2018 strengthened these provisions following the 2012 Delhi case. Your specific rights include: confidentiality protection (Section 228A prohibits revealing a victim's identity), in-camera trials, female officer recording your statement in privacy, free legal aid, medical examination only with consent, and compensation through state victim compensation schemes. There is no statute of limitations for reporting sexual offenses in India. For specialized legal support, contact the National Commission for Women at 1516 or your local District Legal Services Authority.
